newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW-Sybase CEO says products key.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW-Sybase CEO says products key.

text.p: Sybase Inc chief executive officer Mitchell Kertzman said a slew of planned new products and revamped marketing should revive sales growth.
The company has returned to profitability with two back-to-back quarterly profits, including a fourth quarter $0.07 a share that slightly beat Wall Street's estimate.
However, revenues were almost flat in the fourth quarter at $267.8 million versus $267.3 million a year ago.
"We already started," Kertzman said when asked what Sybase will do to grow revenues. "The real driver in 1997 will be a very strong line of products in virtually every area."
Furthermore, Sybase reorganized its marketing approach, he said "with a focus on some vertical markets and a stronger relationship with application vendors," Kertzman said.

He said the new products will span all Sybase's segments from database software, development tools and so-called middleware or software that layers between databases and applications to facilitate things.

Sybase won some large new contracts in the fourth quarter, including one with Federal Express Corp for a range of Sybase products and services. Although the companies would not disclose its value, Sybase said it is about its largest ever.
Kertzman said that ongoing profitability is Sybase's goal. But he said he could not promise or predict profitability.
"We are hoping and planning to be (profitable). The challenge is always is in the first quarter which typically has revenues down from the fourth quarter," he said.
"No goal less than continued profitablity is acceptable," he continued.
He said Sybase's best market opportunity is sales of software for corporate intranets and distributed data markets.
Sybase stumbled into the red unexpectedly in 1995's first quarter and since then has struggled to return to sustained profitability.
Kertzman was promoted to CEO last fall. He had been the CEO of PowerSoft before Sybase acquired it and afterward was second in command to former CEO Mark Hoffman.
Sybase competes in the enterprise database software market which has been growing about 30 percent a year.
Analysts had forecast a profit this quarter, since Sybase completed its restructuring and won some big contracts. Wall Street's mean estimate was $0.06 a share, said First Call Corp.
